blocks.content: An Arduino LED project is a basic yet essential electronics project that introduces you to digital output control. In this project, you'll learn how to use a Light Emitting Diode (LED) to create blinking patterns, adjust brightness via PWM, and build the foundation for more complex circuits. LEDs are widely used in indicator lights, decorative displays, and simple animations in DIY projects.
- Optional: Potentiometer (for PWM brightness control) or transistor (for multiple LEDs)
- Insert the LED into the breadboard. Remember: the longer leg (anode) is positive, and the shorter leg (cathode) is negative.
- Connect the anode of the LED to a digital output pin on the Arduino (for example, pin 13) through a 220-ohm resistor.
- Connect the cathode of the LED to the GND (ground) pin on the Arduino.
- If using a potentiometer for brightness control, connect one side to 5V, the other to GND, and the wiper (middle pin) to an analog input.
- Power up the Arduino by connecting it to your computer or a dedicated power supply.
